prior_works.title: A Linear Non-Gaussian Acyclic Model for Causal Discovery
prior_works.authors: Shohei Shimizu, Patrik O. Hoyer, Aapo Hyvärinen, Antti Kerminen
prior_works.role: Methodological foundation for identifying linear causal graphs via non-Gaussianity (LiNGAM).
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s identifiability and algorithmic approach (LiNGCReL) leverage LiNGAM-style non-Gaussian identifiability to recover a linear latent causal model from mixtures, adapting LiNGAM principles to the causal representation learning setting with multiple environments.

prior_works.title: Variational Autoencoders and Nonlinear ICA: A Unifying Framework
prior_works.authors: Ilyes Khemakhem, Diederik P. Kingma, Ricardo P. Monti, Aapo Hyvärinen
prior_works.role: Establishes identifiability of latent factors using auxiliary variables/environments in nonlinear ICA (iVAE).
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By treating environments as sources of exogenous variation that unlock identifiability, this work motivates the paper’s use of general environments for identifying latent causal variables, while the new paper specializes to linear models and formalizes the exact remaining ambiguity (SNA).

prior_works.title: Causal Inference Using Invariant Prediction: Identification and Confidence Intervals
prior_works.authors: Jonas Peters, Peter Bühlmann, Nicolai Meinshausen
prior_works.role: Introduces invariance across environments as a signal for causal identification (ICP).
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper extends the invariance principle to a latent-variable setting with linear mixing, using cross-environment stability/changes to identify the latent causal structure up to the intrinsic surrounded-node ambiguity.

prior_works.title: Exact Bayesian Structure Learning from Uncertain Interventions
prior_works.role: Analyzes structure learning when interventions occur but targets are unknown/uncertain.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This prior work underpins the paper’s ‘general environments’ assumption—data arise from interventions or shifts with unknown targets—informing both the identifiability framing and the algorithmic handling of multi-target, unknown interventions.

prior_works.title: Challenging Common Assumptions in the Unsupervised Learning of Disentangled Representations
prior_works.authors: Francesco Locatello, Stefan Bauer, Mario Lucic, Gunnar Rätsch, Sylvain Gelly, Bernhard Schölkopf, Olivier Bachem
prior_works.role: Shows impossibility of unsupervised disentanglement without inductive biases or supervision.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This result motivates the paper’s use of multi-environment signals and structural assumptions (linearity, non-Gaussianity) to obtain identifiability guarantees for causal representations that are otherwise unattainable.

prior_works.title: Surrounded-Node Ambiguity in Causal Representation Learning
prior_works.role: Introduces and formalizes the surrounded-node ambiguity (SNA) as an intrinsic non-identifiability in CRL.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper adopts SNA as the fundamental identifiability limit in general environments, proving that even with linear causal models and linear mixing, recovery is only possible up to SNA and providing an algorithm that achieves this optimal identifiability.

synthesis_narrative: The paper’s core advance—identifying linear causal representations from general environments up to the intrinsic surrounded-node ambiguity (SNA), and providing a provable algorithm (LiNGCReL)—rests on three converging lines of prior work. First, LiNGAM (Shimizu et al., 2006) established that linear, non-Gaussian acyclic models are identifiable, giving the methodological backbone for recovering linear causal structure. The new work adapts LiNGAM’s identifiability tools to a latent-variable setting with linear mixing, where only observed mixtures are available across environments. Second, the multi-environment identifiability paradigm (Khemakhem et al., 2020; Peters et al., 2016) shows that exogenous variation across environments—whether framed as auxiliary variables (iVAE) or invariances (ICP)—can unlock identification otherwise impossible from a single environment. The present paper brings these ideas to the latent causal setting with linear mixing, using cross-environment changes as signal while formalizing the precise limit of what can be recovered. Third, the literature on interventions with unknown targets (Eaton & Murphy, 2007) motivates the paper’s ‘general environments’ assumption, where interventions or shifts are present but unspecified, aligning with realistic data collection. Finally, the impossibility of unsupervised disentanglement (Locatello et al., 2019) and the SNA concept (Varici et al., 2023) set the theoretical boundary: without additional structure and environments, recovery is impossible; even with them, SNA remains. The paper’s contribution is to match this boundary—proving identifiability up to SNA in the linear case and delivering an algorithm that achieves it.
